Award.AwardTitle: Conductor-Insulator Transitions in Strongly Correlated Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
****Technical Abstract****
One of the central issues in condensed matter physics is understanding the nature of the ground states in strongly correlated materials, the transitions between those states, and the associated dynamics. This project will seek to answer those questions by conducting a series of linear, non-linear and time-resolved transport measurements on two model experimental systems: two-dimensional electron system in semiconductor heterostructures and underdoped copper oxides. The knowledge gained from those studies will be essential to the development of condensed matter subfields of strongly correlated materials and out-of-equilibrium phenomena. This project will support the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students, who will acquire valuable technical and analytical skills for a wide range of careers in the areas of science and technology in academic, industrial or government settings. The PI and graduate students will also engage in a variety of outreach activities, such as the Annual Open House at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory.

****Non-Technical Abstract****
In many novel materials with potentially great technological importance, such as high-temperature superconductors, the state that conducts electricity (a "conductor") is created by chemically doping an otherwise insulating material. Such materials, therefore, find themselves close to the conductor-insulator transition. Understanding the nature of this transition thus represents an important issue for materials science and technology. It also presents a fundamental problem in condensed matter physics. This project will address the problem of complex behavior near the conductor-insulator transition by performing electrical transport measurements on semiconductor devices and high temperature superconductor materials. The results anticipated from these experiments are expected to provide fundamental insights into these problems, and may be of relevance for future applications. The project will give graduate and undergraduate students an excellent preparation for careers in academia, industry, and government.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this project was on understanding the electronic properties of materials as they undergo transitions between different types of conducting states by varying some external parameter, such as temperature, magnetic field, and density of charge carriers.  Understanding such phase transitions is a fundamental problem in condensed matter physics and it is also of importance for the materials science and technology.  Our studies have led to discoveries relevant to several types of phase transitions, with the most significant outcomes as follows:

  • By using a model system where electrons move in a plane, i.e. in two dimensions (2D), our work identified a new type of a 2D metal-insulator transition (MIT), in which the ever-present impurities (or disorder) play a dominant role.  We established that the properties, or critical exponents, of such a disorder-dominated MIT, are not affected by the range of Coulomb interactions between charge carriers.  We also showed that all known examples of a 2D MIT can be classified into three groups or universality classes.  These results are crucial for developing a microscopic understanding of the MIT, and for the emerging field of novel 2D materials.
  • We established that, as they are warmed up above the superconducting transition temperature, thick films of high-temperature copper-oxide superconductors (cuprates) exhibit the Berezinskii-Kosterlitz-Thouless (BKT) transition, a type of a topological phase transition that occurs in 2D systems.  In these highly anisotropic materials, our work identified the typical transverse length scale that defines the equivalent 2D unit controlling the BKT signatures, and resolved the apparent contradiction between previous studies by other groups.  More importantly, our time-resolved measurements revealed the first experimental evidence of the intrinsic BKT transition dynamics.  These results offer new insights into the dynamics of topological defects across thermal phase transitions.
  • Superconductivity can be also destroyed by high enough magnetic fields.  We showed that in cuprates, in the zero-temperature (quantum) limit, this transition to an insulating state can be a two-stage process.  Our finding of the so-called two quantum critical points goes beyond the conventional theoretical scenario and provides important insights into the effects of magnetic field, temperature, and disorder on superconductivity in cuprates.  In another study, we explored how the presence of charge-ordered states, widely observed in cuprates, modifies this picture.  We discovered that the interplay of high-temperature superconductivity and charge order can give rise to novel states.
  • The dynamics of charge-ordered states is one of the key issues in cuprate high-temperature superconductors.  We discovered that, near the transition to a charge-ordered state, the system can respond to changes in temperature and magnetic field through a series of discrete jumps, or collective rearrangements called avalanches, spanning a broad range of sizes.  The results also reveal the role of disorder and provide a new insight into the phase transitions in systems with intertwined orders.

These findings have been received well by the scientific community, with over 20 invited talks/seminars given nationally and internationally, in addition to the scientific journal publications and a book chapter written by the PI.  The knowledge gained from this project is essential to the development of condensed matter subfields of strongly correlated materials and out-of-equilibrium phenomena.

The project also contributed to the training of two graduate students and two postdoctoral scholars in an area at the forefront of condensed matter physics in a world-class, interdisciplinary multi-user facility.  One doctoral thesis will be completed entirely based on the work supported by this award.  Graduate students and postdoctoral scholars attended conferences to present results of the project.   The research group was diverse: 50% of its members were female, not counting the PI.  The PI was heavily involved in broadening participation of underrepresented groups through a variety of numerous activities, e.g. by serving on a university-wide diversity and inclusion council or as a co-PI on a physics bridge program for students from underrepresented minorities, initially funded by the American Physical Society.  In addition, the PI and the entire research group participated in several outreach activities, including the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory Annual Open House, which attracts general public from all over North Florida and surrounding, rural areas.
